title: 114_hr6175
content: Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include inadmissibility of aliens identified in the terrorist screening database. Additionally, Section 2 addresses the deportability of aliens identified in the same database. Section 237(a)(4)(B) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to exempt lawful permanent residents from deportation if identified in the terrorist screening database. Additionally, Section 3 discusses waivers of inadmissibility for aliens in the same database. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for individual case-by-case basis consideration for granting nonimmigrant visas in the national security interests of the United States. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for temporary admission of nonimmigrants under certain conditions, with a waiver granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security with the unanimous concurrence of key officials. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. Amendments include adding new categories for inadmissibility and deportability. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act related to inadmissibility and deportability for certain nonpermanent residents. It includes changes to sections 240A(b)(1) and 240B(c) regarding cancellation of removal and voluntary departure. The Secretary of Homeland Security will revise regulations related to the Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The revised regulations will allow for reopening and readjudication of past determinations, regardless of when the acts or conditions occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine inadmissibility or deportability and issue removal orders accordingly. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security can issue removal orders to such aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows for the removal of aliens who are inadmissible or deportable on security grounds. An alien described in this paragraph is one who has not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and was not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had conditional permanent resident status at the time proceedings commenced. Expedited proceedings under this subsection will be in accordance with regulations set by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The alien must be given reasonable notice of charges and the opportunity for a hearing. The alien facing removal must have the privilege of choosing counsel, inspecting evidence, ensuring proper identification, maintaining a record for judicial review, and not having the same person issue charges and adjudicate the final removal order. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 days before executing any removal order. The alien must wait 14 days before executing any removal order to allow for judicial review. Additionally, aliens adjudicated inadmissible or deportable are not eligible for discretionary relief from removal. The Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to all aliens in the terrorist screening database from that date.
